For block and allocations, it is checked whether a block and the related unconfirmed allocations can be deleted.

For multi-legged instruments, e.g. IRS, the check is executed only on one elementary transaction per business transaction. For 1 IRS block with 2 allocations, e.g. 3 business transactions each consisting of 2 elementary transactions, 6 all in all, only half of the elementary transactions, 3, are used in the check,

Part of the check is looking for related elementary transactions, and if 1 or more elementary transactions from the not included set of elementary transactions are identified as related, the error message reported on D-92725 is mistakenly given to the user.

For multi-legged instruments, all elementary transactions are now taken into account when checking whether a block and the related unconfirmed allocations can be deleted.

The Benchmark Calculation - Upload Results batch job retrieves SAAM weights from the benchmark calculation and puts this data into files that are uploaded to IAP. If the SAAM definition valid for a specific date is removed, so the date is not covered by a SAAM definition, any existing SAAM weights ought to be deleted. But there is no guarantee that they are deleted. The data can therefore be considered as "dead data". The benchmark calculation upload results job would still retrieve this "dead data" and put it into the files that are uploaded to IAP and this could result in validation errors in the data ingest process.

The retrieval of SAAM weights have been enhanced, so SAAM weights on a given date is only retrieved for portfolios that have a SAAM definition on the date.

If having many transactions being rescheduled (e.g. due to waiting for linked transactions) the processing of transactions could take long time, as the services over and over again tried to process the transactions which were rescheduled over and over again. Before the service processed the transactions in creation order (CRETS). Now the service will take the expire time into consideration, and the transactions will be processed in MAX(CRETS,EXPIRETIME) order, meaning if EXPIRETIME is after CRETS, it’s the EXPIRETIME which will be used when deciding the order.

If using multiple columns IN, and one or more columns always has the same value, the columns will be removed from the IN and instead added as equal. 
E.g. (COLA, COLB,COLC) IN ((1,2,3)(3,4,3)(5,6,3)) will be replaced with (COLA,COLB) IN ((1,2)(3,4)(5,6)) AND COLC=3

In OTC Search OData API Date and DateTime  with provided time part in queries were not treated as local date time (server local date time), which created inconsistencies when querying the data. Now the date and time provided will be converted local date time (server date time). ISO 8601 format should be used and following formats are supported: 2021-01-22, 2021-01-22T10:00:00Z, 2021-01-22T10:00:00+05:00. For the properties that are just dates it is recommended to use only this format "2021-01-22", dropping time part. Otherwise the time provided in UTC or with offset would need to match the midnight in local server time.

A correction is made to the factor based FIPA fair cash flow on decomposed spot legs of IRF positions in Performance Calculation. This affects the fair cash flow itself as well as the factor based FIPA local return, when this is calculated using the TWR based approach. The correction ensures that the cash flow adjustment is consistently based on exposure, which removes spikes in the factor based FIPA local return on decomposed IRF positions on days with buy or sell transactions.
